III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Eligibility requirements.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12504
Section (1) An agency shall document the rationale for selection of
Description independent living as the most appropriate placement for the
youth.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The youth is struggling with suicidal ideations and has had self-
harming behavior. She has seven to ten one-inch cuts on her right
arm from an incident today. There are concerns the youth was
placed in the facility inappropriately by the agency.
Investigation Interviews:
On 3/27/2024 I interviewed the Chief Administrator (CA) about
this allegation by telephone. I spoke to the CA again face-to-face
at the independent living (IL) house on 3/28/2024; and a third time
2

face-to-face at the agency’s administrative office on 4/5/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS (Michigan Department of Health and
Human Services) Worker XX (MDHHS Worker XXX) was also
present observing the interview).
The CA confirmed Youth A’s placement with the agency. She
reported Spectrum did not know about Youth A’s current suicidal
ideations and self-harming behaviors when they agreed to Youth
A’s placement. She described the agency’s intake process. The
referring agency provides various documents to Spectrum, which
she and the agency’s Intake Worker reviews, discusses; and
thereafter decides whether to admit the youth for placement. The
CA reported she makes the final decision as to whom to accept in
the program. She said an intake meeting with the potential youth
occurs; and in most cases there would be a TDM (Team Decision
Meeting) related to the youth prior to placement occurring. In this
instance, with Youth A, a TDM occurred on 3/18/2024. During that
TDM it was discussed that Youth A was feeling alone. The CA
said that was likely connected to the fact that Youth A had only
been in the home for three days and had not yet entered into
school. The CA reported they surmised once Youth A got into
school, she would feel better. The CA denied anyone reporting
during the TDM that Youth A was having suicidal ideations or self-
harming behaviors. Nor did anyone report how Youth A reacts to
new placements, or Youth A might do so by self-harming. The CA
admitted a safety plan was mentioned, but this was in connection
to MDHHS-POS (Purchase of Service) Worker Y reporting Youth
A has anxiety, but no specifics.
The CA reported based on the referral package/information
received; and what was reported about Youth A before placement,
Youth A met their program’s eligibility criteria. She reported it was
reported by Youth A’s previous placement, Vista Maria, that
agency’s IL program was less appropriate for Youth A as Youth A
needed a smaller house environment like Spectrum’s IL program.
The CA reported Spectrum’s Whitehorn IL house, where Youth A
is placed is a smaller setting. It normally houses only three youths;
and it reopened to take placement of Youth A. She reported
MDHHS-POS Worker Y; and Youth A knew upfront that Youth A
would be the only youth in the house for a while.
The CA expressed concern that MDHHS and Vista Maria did not
share all appropriate information and details related to Youth A’s
self-harming behavior or level of need. She said she went back
and reviewed the referral information to see if she had missed
anything about Youth A, around her self-harming; and she had
3

not. She initially acknowledged knowing Youth A’s past
hospitalization in December 2023 pertaining to suicidal ideations,
but later reported only becoming aware of Youth A’s suicidal/ self-
harming behaviors on 3/23/2023, when an outside source
contacted the police to report Youth A was feeling suicidal. The
CA subsequently clarified she didn’t know these behaviors were
current.
The CA reported after Youth A’s first hospital visit/ incident on
3/23/2024, she began staffing Whitehorn IL house 24 hours a day
(as opposed to the program’s contractual required16 hours), so as
to provide supervision to Youth A, after Youth A’s self-harming
issues, they also put a written safety plan in place. The CA stated
Spectrum does take youths with a history of self-harming,
behavior, but they did not know those behaviors were active for
Youth A at the time of Youth A ‘s placement. The CA said Youth
A’s hospitalization for suicidal ideation would not have been a red
flag against placing Youth A in their program. They look for three
months of stable behavior; and Youth A appeared to have had
that. She reported if there had been an incident of self-harming for
Youth A in January or February of 2024, that would have been a
red flag; and they would not have accepted Youth A.
The CA reported around 3/25/2023 Spectrum was talking with
MDHHS about Spectrum’s IL placement not being appropriate for
Youth A. The CA advised MDHHS that Spectrum could not
accommodate Youth A for 30 days; and asked for a TDM for
replacement consideration. The CA thought residential may be a
better fit for Youth A. MDHHS did not agree, they indicated
exploration of a relative. The TDM was pending for 4/3/2024.
On 3/28/2024 I interviewed the IL Case Manager about this
allegation by telephone while I was onsite at the IL home. I also
interviewed the Case Manager face-to-face at the agency’s
administrative office on 4/5/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS
Worker XX (MDHHS Worker XXX was also present observing the
interview). The Case manager reported the CA and Intake
Worker takes care of the IL homes’ placements. She said she is
normally present at TDMs around placements, but she was not
included in Youth A’s. She was not able to say whether MDHHS
had indicated a safety plan needed to be in place for Youth A at
placement; nor whether a need for safety would be a red flag
against placement. She reported not getting that information from
MDHHS; and not being able to make such a determination about
placement without having seen the specific safety plan MDHHS
may have had or indicated.
4

On 4/3/2024, I interviewed Youth A’s MDHHS-POS Worker Y by
telephone. MDHHS-POS Worker Y reported she made the
placement of Youth A in Spectrum’s IL program. She said, she is
aware of Youth A’s reports that Youth A was not ready for
placement but that was not what Youth A had reported before
placement. She reported Youth A’s prior placement was at Vista
Maria; and as Youth A’s worker she had regular contact with the
Vista Maria staff and Youth A’s therapist about Youth A and Youth
A’s readiness for replacement from the Vista Maria program. A
week prior to Youth A’s placement with Spectrum, MDHHS-POS
Worker Y said she spoke with Vista Maria Therapist (VMT) about
perhaps not having Youth A move. The VMT advised if Youth A
was not allowed to leave it would be a monumental mental health
setback for Youth A. MDHHS- POS Worker Y admitted she had
some concerns, but she was going with the therapist’s
recommendation; and that fact Youth A had made huge
improvements. Youth A also said she was ready, and they had to
give Youth A a chance in a less structured setting. She reported
Youth A did not go into Vista Maria’s IL program on that agency’s
residential site, because that program said to wait for Youth A to
have an additional 30 days without any incidents, and they would
take her. Everyone said Youth A was ready to leave Vista Maria
for a less structured program. The VMT expressed if they waited
to have Youth A go into an IL program Youth A could back-slide
and her behaviors of suicidal ideation might return. Thus, the
Spectrum IL placement occurred as Spectrum was able to take
Youth A sooner.
MDHHS-POS Worker Y said she and Vista Maria thought Youth A
might have a rocky start, may have some acting out behaviors,
which could include suicidal ideations or self-harm, but Youth A
would settle in once Youth A saw that she would not be rejected.
MDHHS-POS Worker Y could not recall whether she told
Spectrum Youth A could likely self-harm. She reported, if she
didn’t tell Spectrum this, she did give them all the incident reports
for Youth A, and Vista Maria also gave them paperwork about
Youth A’s history. She said there was also a TDM on 3/18/204, a
few day after Youth A’s placement. At that TDM it was mentioned
Youth A would have a transition period. She said during Youth A’s
transition periods Youth A acts out by self-harming. MDHHS-POS
Worker Y did not remember if that was told to Spectrum at the
TDM. She reported she would not have moved forward with
Youth A’s IL placement if she thought Youth A would not have
been safe in placement. She reported Youth A’s thoughts of
5

suicide/self-harm after the Spectrum placement may have been
set off by a loss Youth A learned about.
On 4/11/2024 MDHHS Worker XX and I interviewed the Intake
Worker by telephone. The Intake Worker reported MDHHS- POS
Worker Y sent Spectrum a referral form on 1/9/2024, and she sent
MDHHS- POS Worker Y a referral document to complete/of the
package of information Spectrum would need. She reported what
the CA had related to who reviews the placement
referral/information package and who makes the final decision
about a youth’s acceptance in the program. She also reported
based on the information Spectrum received it was determined
Youth A was appropriate for their IL program.
The Intake Worker also affirmed Youth A’s intake interview at
placement on 3/14/2024. Youth A was advised the Whitehorn IL
house was reopening, Youth A would be the only youth in the
home, and staff would be there some hours. Additionally, she
affirmed the CA’s reporting related the agency’s looking to see
that a youth has a three-month window of a lack of active mental
health issues to be considered for placement. She reported a
youth having suicidal ideations would be a red flag for her and
reason for discussion with the CA due to the level of
independence a youth needs be in their IL programs. She denied
there being any reports by MDHHS or in the referral material, that
Youth A needed greater supervision. She did not recall there
being information in Youth A’s referral package related to Youth A
being hospitalized for suicidal ideations.
On 4/15/2024 I interviewed the Vista Maria Therapist (VMT) by
telephone. The VMT reported Youth A was in Vista Maria’s short
term treatment program from 11/14/2/2023 until 3/14/2024.
Youth A initially spent more time in the hospital than in the
program. After Youth A’s 12/1/2023- 12/13/2023 hospital stay
Youth A committed to treatment; did very well; and Youth A was
interviewed for different placements. Youth A interviewed with
Vista Maria’s Shepherd Hall’s IL program on 2/13/2024; and
Spectrum’s IL program on 2/5/2024. Vista Maria’s IL program was
open to accepting placement of Youth A, but they wanted 40 more
days of stability. The Spectrum program was able to take Youth A
sooner. Also, Youth A wanted a community-based placement,
which Vista Maria’s Shepherd Hall IL program is less like; and was
perceived by Youth A that way. The VMT reported Youth A was
nervous about going into IL placement, but Youth A was ready for
the placement. Youth A had come from a community level IL
6

placement, and Youth A’s choice was Spectrum’s IL program over
the Shepherd Hall’s IL program.
The VMT reported being in attendance of Youth A’s TDM along
with the Spectrum’s Intake Worker and MDHHS-POS Worker Y.
She did recall whether there was discussion with Spectrum about
how Youth A behaves when Youth A goes into a new placement.
She recalled MDHHS-POS Worker Y’s discussion of a safety plan
related to if Youth A was to feel unsafe. MDHHS-POS Worker Y
verbalized removing all sharp object. The VMT was not sure who
was to complete that safety plan but recalled an email from the
Spectrum’s Intake Worker to MDHHS-POS Worker Y asking
MDHHS-POS Worker Y if MDHHS completed that safety plan.
Spectrum needed to include it in Youth A’s file. MDHHS-POS
Worker Y response to Spectrum Intake Worker was MDHHS-POS
Worker Y did not recall she was to complete the safety plans, that
the safety plan was to be formulated from the discussion at the
TDM. Spectrum Intake Worker replied to MDHHS-POS Worker Y,
this was to be provided by MDHHS.
Document Review.
• Youth A’s MISACWIS case record which showed she is a
permanent court ward, who has had numerous placements,
inclusive of a number of past residential placements.
• A Referral to Spectrum completed by MDHHS that
indicated Youth A has demonstrated she, can be left alone
in the home unsupervised and in the community; can be
unsupervised for at least three hours; has demonstrated
she can handle emergencies. That IL will assist her in
developing life skills to live independently. Additionally,
Youth A continued area for growth was in mental health,
education, and financial literacy.
• Referral data provided on Youth A that indicated
information as alluded to in this report. It also showed
Youth A’s last hospital stay was 12/1/2023-12/13/2023.
• Spectrum’s IL program statement, which showed per the
referral data Youth A, age 16, met the program’s
requirements, at the time.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per staff and collateral
interviews, Youth A was not showing active signs of suicidal
ideation or self-harming behaviors at the time of her placement or
since December 2023; she met the agency’s criteria for placement
at that time. Additionally, Youth A’s MDHHS-POS Worker and
prior therapist had advised the agency Youth A was ready for
placement in a community-based IL placement.
7

Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code Supervision.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12505
Section (1) An agency shall provide supervision for a youth in independent
Description living consistent with the youth's need for supervision, as required
by R 400.12504(2)(e).
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation (1) The youth is struggling with suicidal ideations and informed
staff they wanted to harm themselves, but it was not taken
seriously. Youth has seven to ten one-inch cuts on her right arm
from today. It is unknown if staff sought medical treatment for
concerns. There are concerns of a lack staff supervision for this
16-year-old youth, who was home alone when she was having
thoughts of self-harm.
(2) On 3/27/2024, EMS were called to a residence in Saline
Township where the youth was with a friend. The youth and her
friend had taken edible gummies. The youth was paranoid and
making suicidal ideations. The youth has new self-harming marks
on her left arm. The youth was taken to the hospital for her
suicidal ideations. It is unknown who was supervising the youth.
Investigation Interviews:
Allegation (1)
On 3/27/2024 I interviewed the CA about this allegation by
telephone. I spoke with the CA again about the allegations face-
to-face at the agency’s Whitehorn IL house on 3/28/2024; and
face-to-face at the agency’s administrative office on 4/5/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker XX (MDHHS Worker XXX was
also present observing the interview)
The CA denied the allegations. On 3/27/2024. she reported Youth
A had gone to the hospital three or four times since Youth A’s
3/14/2024 placement date; and each time the hospital had
released Youth A. She reported Youth A’s initial thoughts of
suicide and self-harming came to the agency’s attention after
Youth A posted something on social media and a friend/outside
source called the police on two separate occasions. In each of
those incidents, first on 3/23/2024, then on 3/25/2024 the police
showed up at the IL house and reported the incident. Youth A was
taken to the hospital by EMS and a staff accompanied Youth A.
The CA reported Youth A had not informed them/the staff onsite of
8

her suicidal thoughts or self-harming. The CA reported each time
Youth A has reported suicidal or harmful thoughts to staff, they
have taken her to the hospital. She reported Youth A seemed to
have been trying get to a specific hospital, where Youth A thought
they would keep her. Youth A had reported she wanted to get
admitted, to stay at a hospital for two weeks; that she would be
okay after such an admission. The CA said Youth A had not
displayed or reported any incidents of suicidal thoughts or self-
harming behaviors prior to 3/23/2024. The only unusual incident
was related to Youth A dying her hair black.
The CA reported after Youth A’s first hospital visit/incident on
3/23/2024, she began staffing the IL house 24 hours a day (as
opposed to the program’s contractual required16 hours), so as to
provide supervision to Youth A. She said a staff person was at the
home with Youth A both on 3/23/2024 and 3/25/2024. Youth
Worker 3 was the staff on shift at the time of 3/25/2024 reported
incident; and Youth Worker 1 the staff on shift at the time of the
3/23/2023 reported incident The CA reported, they also put a
written safety plan in place. She reported the later plan was
something other than some type of plan the MDHHS-POS Worker
Y had wanted prior to these incidents, and which the CA had
asked the Intake Worker to follow up on. The CA reported she
instructed, the Case Manager and the team to put the safety plan
in place on 3/23/2024. (The CA had provided a copy of that written
safety plan to me on 3/27/2024). The safety plan was dated
3/22/2024, signed by the Case Manager for that date, and signed
by Youth A on 3/26/2024. The CA believed the Case Manager
placed the incorrect date on the plan, that it should have been
dated 3/23/2024. She reported the staff had been advised verbally
of the safety concerns, to check on Youth A every 15 minutes,
monitor closer, to keep her bedroom door open, the bathroom ajar
when Youth A is inside, and to call the Crisis line Hotline if Youth
A reported suicidal/harmful thoughts/concerns. On 3/25/2024 she
told staff to check the youth’s belonging for sharp objects and to
remove them. She reported they do not keep sharp items, like
knifes out in the home. Also, that given, they are an IL program
they do not normally go through a youth’s belonging to check for
objects. They ask the youths whether they have any weapon, cell
phones, etc. and document the items. She said youth are allowed
to have a razor but not razor blades, which was what Youth A
reportedly used to scratch/cut the various marks on Youth A' arm.
The CA said the staff were following the safety plan
recommendations.
9

On 3/28/2024 I interviewed the Case Manager about this
allegation by telephone, while I was onsite at the IL home. I also
interviewed the Case Manager face-to-face at the agency’s
administrative office on 4/5/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS
Worker XX (MDHHS Worker XXX was also present observing the
interview). The Case manager reported meeting with Youth A
approximately six times since Youth A’s 3/14/2024 placement; and
Youth A had gone to the hospital several times since 3/23/2024.
She confirmed the CA’s reporting as to how Youth A’s incident of
suicidal thoughts and self-harming behavior came to the agency’s
attention on 3/23/2024 and 3/25/2024, and the hospital’s repeated
discharge of Youth A. She said on 3/23/2024 staff had seen
Youth A on her tablet, but staff did not know Youth A was posting
any concerns or thoughts of self-harm or suicidal ideation. Staff
thought Youth A was talking and interacting with a friend. The
Case Manager reported the staff took Youth A to the hospital a
few times after that; and staff provided supervision to Youth A at
the hospital both when Youth A was transported by the EMS and
when staff took Youth A. The Case Manager said she received
those incident reports. She reported after Youth A went to the
hospital for the cutting of Youth A’s arm on 3/25/2024, staff asked
the psychiatrist why the hospital was not keeping Youth A. The
hospital advised the staff the hospital was referring Youth A to a
therapist and Youth A was being discharged. The Case Manager
reported Youth A went back to the hospital a second time on
3/25/2024 because Youth A reported having suicidal thoughts.
Staff called the Crisis Hotline and were advised to take Youth A
back to the hospital. Staff took Youth A to the hospital in Taylor.
Youth A didn’t want to go there. Youth A wanted to go to
Annapolis hospital, because she thought her chances of getting
admitted would be better. Youth A was discharged from that visit
on 3/26/2024 around 6:30pm. Then on 3/27/2024. Youth A left
the IL house and was involved in another incident that lead to
another hospital visit and overnight stay.
The Case Manager reported meeting with Youth A at the IL house
after the first incident on 3/25/2024. Youth A had several cut
marks on her arm. Youth A told her Youth A was going to “keep
doing it” (Youth A didn’t clarify) until the hospital admitted her.
Youth A reported she used a razor blade to cut her arm. Youth A
reported having the razor blade in a box of things she brought
from Vista Maria. The Case Manager said a safety plan was
developed; she met with Youth A about the safety plan and Youth
A agreed to it and signed the plan.
10

Case Manager reported the discrepancy with the dates on the
safety plan. She said she must have also met with Youth A on
3/26/2024, after Youth A came home from the hospital. She
reported she had started the safety plan on 3/22/2023 based on
MDHHS telling someone (the Case Manager did not say whom) at
Spectrum that a safety plan was needed, but the Case Manager
did not know why. She said she spoke with the staff about
monitoring Youth A, and if Youth A exhibited or indicated anything
around wanting to harm herself the staff was to contact the Crisis
Hotline. She did not recall instructions to staff around removing
possible items from Youth A’s room, until after the incident of
Youth A cutting on 3/25/2024. She believed staffing at the IL
home changed to 24-hour supervision after Youth A’s reported
incident on 3/23/2024; but since she does not handle staff
scheduling, she was not sure of this. She reported prior to Youth
A’s incidents of self-harming staff were monitoring Youth A as they
would any other IL youth. There is nothing in their policy that
requires line of site supervision for IL youths. She said, after Youth
A’s suicidal thoughts incident, and act of self-harming, the staff
were instructed to monitor her every 15 minutes, and as
previously reported by the CA.
On 3/28/2024 I interviewed Complainant X about this allegation
by telephone. Complainant X reported knowing Youth A and
Youth B from their placement at another facility; and to being a
person who set up a crisis intervention program for them. She
reported on 3/23/2024 Youth A and Youth B were on a video call
via snapchat; and Youth A put a statement out that she was going
to self-harm. The two youths were talking out loud, as Youth A
walked around the house. Youth A told Youth B she had not
taken her medication in 24-hours, and she had started to
hallucinate. Youth A told Youth B there was not a staff at the IL
home, and one would not be there until 3:00am. Complainant X
reported feeling Youth A could be hallucinating, and she advised
Youth A she had an obligation to call the police. Complainant
called 911 around 7:55pm and the police arrived at the home
between 8:10-8:15pm.
Complainant X reported as Youth A was walking around the
house, she did not observe a staff there. She said the staff person
and police arrived around the same time. The staff asked what
was going on. Complainant X reported from what she could tell
the staff had come from the outside as opposed to another part of
the house because Youth A had been sitting by the front door.
Complainant X reported Youth A did not know the staff’s name
and had reported that staff had left the home at 1:30pm. Youth A
11

also reported during her conservation with Youth B, Youth A told
the staff before that staff left that she felt anxious, didn’t feel safe,
and she wanted to harm herself. Youth A said that staff told her
“that’s your problem and that’s on you if you choose to do that”.
Complainant X reported being concerned for Youth A.
Complainant X reported calling the police a second time on Youth
A’s behalf on 3/25/2024. She reported sometime after 2:00pm
that day, she learned Youth A was sending pictures of cuts Youth
A was making to Youth A’s arm to a friend. Complainant X did not
see the photo but assessed that Youth A was in crisis at that
moment. She called the police; and the police made a home visit.
Complainant X denied suggesting to Youth A that Youth A needed
to be hospitalized for a few weeks to stabilize herself. She
reported having a conversation with Youth A about Youth A self-
harming and explained to Youth A if she was going to keep self-
harming it may be best for Youth A to get into a crisis intervention
program to have her medication evaluated and adjusted, if need.
Complainant X did not report contacting the IL staff or agency
administrator about her concerns with this youth.
On 3/28/2024 I interviewed Youth A about this allegation face-to-
face at Trinity hospital in Ypsilanti, MI. Youth A denied being told
she would be the only youth in the home. She said the IL Intake
Worker completed her intake and told her a staff person would be
at the home morning, noon and night. She said a staff person
was with her when she arrived at the placement the afternoon of
3/14/2024; and all day the next few days after that. Youth A
reported one day, the following week, Youth A could not call which
day, she left the IL home, and when she returned around 3:00pm
no staff was on site until around 9:00pm. Youth A reported this
was the day she was over thinking, and a lot was going on in her
mind. She said she was facetiming with her friend, Youth B. She
told Youth B how she was feeling, and Youth B called the police
about her negative feelings. Youth A said she did not call or tell
the staff on duty how she was feeling, because no staff was there.
She did know that staff name, but reported the staff arrived at the
house about five minutes before the police arrived. Youth A said
the staff asked the police what was going on, suggesting the staff
was in fact onsite, somewhere prior to the police’s arrival. She
said the police took her to Beaumont Wayne hospital, but the
hospital did not admit her. She said she was feeling the same as
when she got there, but the hospital only kept her for 24-hours.
The hospital discharged her with a referral to New Oakland Family
Service for mental health services. Youth A said the following day
staff were with her all day and night. She said she went back to
12

the hospital on 3/25/2024. She reported that she woke up feeling
terrible and she carved up her arm. She allowed me to view her
left forearm, which had numerous superficial scratch marks on it.
The wording “Fat Pig” was also carved into her left forearm. The
cuts did not appear deep, there was no bleeding, nor bandaging.
Youth A reported using a razor blade from her art stuff. She had
the item in a bag she brought from her last placement. She said
staff do not check bags, but once they learned of this, the staff
took the razor blade, and later they searched her belongings, and
removed various items, sharp objects from the house. She said,
the staff found out she had self-harmed that day from the police.
She called Youth B; Youth B called the police. The police came
